prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HUDF-1 3mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal targets the CO(2-1) line in HUDF-1 at 3mm. We propose to use the C36-6 or C36-7 array configuration in order to achieve a resolution of 0.3"-0.1" (corresponding to 2.3-1.0 kpc at the redshift of the source). These high-resolution data will be combined with the low-resolution data already in hand in order to complete the uv coverage.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The observed line width of HUDF-1 is ~770 km/s. We opt for the largest bandwith (1.875 GHz per spw) in order to maximize the velocity and continuum coverage, and to rebin to 4 channels (~6 km/s) to keep a relatively low data rate. Thanks to the CO observations already in hand, we precisely know the frequency of the targeted line.

Our science goals require that our CO observations match the exquisite resolution of the HST data -- this will allow a 1-to-1 comparison between stellar emission, unobscured star formation, dust extinction (from the HST images) and molecular gas and dust emission (from the proposed ALMA observations). We therefore require C36-6 or C36-7 array observations in order to reach angular resolutions of 0.3"--0.1". The sources targeted in this study are sufficiently small in terms of angular size that spatial filtering will not be an issue. Furthermore, we will combine the proposed observations with the low-resolution ALMA data already in hand, in order to maximize the uv coverage.

The targeted line has an observed flux of ~2.1 Jy km/s (~1.4 mJy/beam x 770 km/s over 2 beams -- the spectrum in Fig.1 has not been corrected for primary beam attenuation, which accounts for a factor ~1.5). Our detailed analysis of the superb HST images of HUDF-1 suggests that ~50% of the CO emission will be associated with the central ~15 resolution elements (see Fig. 1). This implies an average expected flux of 45 uJy/beam. We set this as our target rms. Combining these data with the low-resolution observations already in hand will push the achieved sensitivity further down by a factor ~1.5. Assuming standard conversion factors, this limit will imply a Sigma_gas limit of ~470 Msun/pc2, i.e., about a factor ~2.2 deeper than the limit achieved in GN20 with >100 hr of integration with JVLA (see Fig.2, right).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HUDF-2 3mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal targets the CO(3-2) line in HUDF-2 at 3mm. We propose to use the C36-6 or C36-7 array configuration in order to achieve a resolution of 0.3"-0.1" (corresponding to 2.3-1.0 kpc at the redshift of the source). These high-resolution data will be combined with the low-resolution data already in hand in order to complete the uv coverage.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The observed line width of HUDF-2 is ~700 km/s. We opt for the largest bandwith (1.875 GHz per spw) in order to maximize the velocity and continuum coverage, and to rebin to 4 channels (~6 km/s) to keep a relatively low data rate. Thanks to the CO observations already in hand, we precisely know the frequency of the targeted line.

Our science goals require that our CO observations match the exquisite resolution of the HST data -- this will allow a 1-to-1 comparison between stellar emission, unobscured star formation, dust extinction (from the HST images) and molecular gas and dust emission (from the proposed ALMA observations). We therefore propose to use the array in C36-6 or C36-7 configuration, in order to achieve a resolution of 0.3"-0.1". The sources targeted in this study are sufficiently small in terms of angular size that spatial filtering will not be an issue. Furthermore, we will combine the proposed observations with the low-resolution ALMA data already in hand, in order to maximize the uv coverage.

The targeted line has an observed flux of ~0.9 Jy km/s (~1.3 mJy/beam x 700 km/s). Our detailed analysis of the superb HST images of HUDF-2 suggests that the >50% of the CO emission will be associated with the prominent dust lane, which will cover ~12 resolution elements in the proposed observations (see simulations in Fig. 1). This implies an average expected flux of 55 uJy/beam. We set this as our target rms. Combining these data with the low-resolution observations already in hand will push the achieved sensitivity further down by a factor ~1.5. Assuming standard conversion factors, this limit will imply a Sigma_gas limit of ~600 Msun/pc2, i.e., about a factor ~1.8 deeper than the limit achieved in GN20 with >100 hr of integration with JVLA (see Fig. 2, right).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HUDF 0.7mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal targets the sub-mm dust continuum in HUDF-1 and HUDF-2 at 0.7mm. We propose to use the C36-4 array configuration in order to achieve a resolution of 0.13" = 1.0 kpc at the redshift of the source.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We opt for the largest available bandwidth, in order to maximize the continuum sensitivity. We will rebin to 4 channels (~6 km/s) in order to keep a relatively low data rate. We tune our continuum observations in order to cover the CO(11-10) line in HUDF-2 (which shows high CO excitation). However, we stress that this high-J CO detection is not a main goal of the present project.

Our science goals require that our dust continuum observations match the exquisite resolution of the HST data -- this will allow a 1-to-1 comparison between stellar emission, unobscured star formation, dust extinction (from the HST images) and molecular gas and dust emission (from the proposed ALMA observations). Our target resolution is therefore 0.14", which can be achieved with C36-5 observations. The sources targeted in this study are sufficiently small in terms of angular size that spatial filtering will not be an issue. Furthermore, we will combine the proposed observations with the low-resolution ALMA data already in hand, in order to maximize the uv coverage.

In our ALMA Cycle 2 observations of the HUDF at 1mm, HUDF-1 and 2 show a dust continuum flux density of 0.13 and 0.6 mJy per beam respectively. Extrapolating at 357 GHz, this yields 0.45 and 1.63 mJy per beam respectively. Our simulations, based on the dust map created from the HST images (see Fig. 1), suggest that the flux will be spread over 15 (12) resolution elements in HUDF-1 (HUDF-2). Therefore, we set our 1-sigma continuum sensitivity request to 30 uJy per beam. Assuming standard conversion factors, this implies a 1-sigma limit on Sigma_SFR of ~5 Msun/pc2, i.e., 1.5 times deeper than the values targeted in GN20 by Hodge et al. (2015) (see Fig. 2).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Most of what we currently know about molecular gas in high-z galaxies stems from targeted observations of galaxies, pre-selected based on their star formation, stellar mass, or nuclear activity. To overcome this limitation, we performed a blind census of molecular gas in the Hubble Ultra Deep Field with ALMA. These Cycle 2 data reveal two very strong CO and dust detections. These two galaxies are the largest cold gas reservoirs in the field. Yet, they would not have been obvious traditional targets for CO follow-ups, based on their stellar mass or star formation. Here we propose to obtain dust continuum and CO line maps for these cold-gas selected galaxies, at a resolution matching the deep HST imaging. These will reveal 1) the dust and gas distribution and morphology: is the cold ISM organized in massive clumps? 2) the galaxy dynamics, and 3) the star-formation efficiency through the resolved comparison of star formation rate and the gas reservoir. These observations will reveal the structure, dynamics, and star formation efficiency in these cold-gas selected galaxies, and are an important step towards fully characterizing the molecular gas and dust content in UDF galaxies.
